title: Aboriginal Australian Words in English
description: From kangaroo to boomerang, discover the Aboriginal Australian language origins of iconic English words!

questions.question: The word 'kangaroo' is believed to come from the Guugu Yimithirr language. What did the original word 'gangurru' refer to?
options: A specific species of large grey kangaroo

questions.question: Which English word for a curved throwing stick comes from the Dharuk language of the Sydney region?
The word 'koala' comes from the Dharuk word 'gula.' What does it supposedly mean?
options: No water (referring to the animal rarely drinking)

questions.question: Which word for a wild dog of Australia comes from the Dharuk language?
The word 'wombat' comes from the Dharuk language. What is distinctive about wombats?
Which type of Australian tree gets its English name from the Dharuk word 'waratah'?
The word 'budgerigar' (budgie) comes from the Gamilaraay language. What does the original word roughly mean?
options: Good to eat or good food

questions.question: Which musical instrument's name comes from an Aboriginal Australian language?
The word 'billabong' is used in English, famously in 'Waltzing Matilda.' What is a billabong?
options: A stagnant pool or oxbow lake left by a river

questions.question: Which word for a spear-throwing device comes from the Dharuk language?
The word 'barramundi' (a popular fish) comes from an Aboriginal language. What does it mean?
Which word for an Australian shrubland or bushland comes from an Aboriginal language?
The word 'corroboree' from the Dharuk language refers to what type of Aboriginal event?
options: A ceremonial gathering with dance and music

questions.question: Which Australian animal's name, 'quokka,' comes from the Nyungar language of Western Australia?
The word 'yakka' (meaning 'work' in Australian English) comes from the Yagara language. In what context is it commonly used?
options: In the phrase 'hard yakka' meaning hard work
